text: thank you for coming to my talk and thank you to
ndc and all the organizers and sponsors for making this talk happen my name
is melissa halton and i am a senior developer from tulsa purple based in melbourne
australia my accents might be a little bit weird because i'm originally from california
so it's become a bit of a blend of the two but i'm a tech consultant
who works in web development mostly with angular and net i know this conference
has a pretty big c plus plus focus which i haven't worked with so i won't really be able to contribute
much on on that topic but i would still like to connect virtually with all of you
and i'm gonna try and stay up and attend some sessions after this it is night
time over where i'm at um my socials are up on the screen so if you did want to connect in that way or tweet
along as i'm going on with this talk please please do that i am disappointed that we weren't able
to meet in person this year because i've actually i've never been over to norway and it's it's on my list of places to go
but hopefully in the future um i'll have a chance to go over there and maybe we can meet in person and
maybe you'll even see me at another ndc tech town so this is my my very first
full virtual presentation so do let me know if there's any issues with the sound or hearing me or
something with this stream i have turned on um the subtitles within powerpoint
i don't know how accurate they are but hopefully it helps if there is any issues with the sound um and my
slides are mostly just pretty pictures to distract you from looking at me so if there's any uh problems with the video streaming
that shouldn't really be a big problem either um but otherwise please hold your
questions until the end i'll check the slack at the end we should have a bit of time for discussion and
questions imposter syndrome how many of you have
heard of imposter syndrome if we were in person i would ask you to raise your hands and
i would expect to see many hands raised and if you would not
have raised your hand that's okay too you're in the right place this is not a new topic it's been
covered hundreds of times in many different ways when i was doing research for this talk
i found hundreds of ted talks and articles publications and books blog posts
by many different people there were talks by psychologists educators students
and business professionals and people from all different backgrounds different genders different ethnicities
and different professional standing they all shared their research on imposter syndrome but
most importantly they shared their personal experiences of it
if we look to famous people we can see faces that we might recognize of people who have shared feelings of
imposter syndrome we have maya angelou a poet and american civil rights activist
she's an author with dozens of awards for her work but she has shared fears that people
will find out she's just been playing a game on them the whole time lady gaga a musician who strives to be
different and is considered considered by some as the world's best music artist
in her documentary she said that she feels still like that loser kid in high school
and has to remind herself every single day that she's she's a superstar now serena
williams a professional tennis player and former number one in the world at women's single tennis
she has 23 grand slam titles to her name but despite the success she
feels like she lives under her sister's shadow and she struggles to rationalize
her success as her own if we go a little bit closer to home
into the tech community and for me within australia we find familiar faces there as well so
mike kennen brooks from atlassian one of the ceos and founders has a tedx talk that he's done on
imposter syndrome and in his talk he shares his story with imposter syndrome and his personal
battle against it he shares his story of how when atlassian was up and coming as a brand new tech
company and he was winning entrepreneur of the year awards he was feeling like a fraud and in this
in this process he learned that others felt the same and that that feeling does not go away
with success but he learned how to not let it hold him back how not to freeze
and how to use his fear as motivation and we can do that too
clinical psychologists pauline clance and suzanne ims first defined imposter syndrome in 1978
and they defined it as an internal experience of intellectual phoniness despite
outstanding academic and professional accomplishments so their study focused on high
achieving women specifically but many studies have been done later that have proven that imposter syndrome is
prevalent across all genders it's also known by a few other names such as imposter
phenomenon imposterism and fraud syndrome but whatever you want to call it it's
when you feel like a fraud that you do not deserve your success or your achievements
that you you have a fear that you're about to be found out it's the inability to internalize your
achievements so why do people experience imposter syndrome
who experiences it what does it look like how can we battle against it and how can
we help others to battle against it and how can we flip it around and turn it into something positive
well that's what i want to talk to you about today but first why me why am i the one
sitting here talking to you well i constantly ask myself the same question
but my very first conference talk was on the same subject and it was
at a talk in sydney called ddd sydney but it was no ordinary talk it was
actually the lock note and when i first heard that d d sydney
wanted me for the lock note i thought it must be a prank
it was my last night in perth before moving completely across the country over to melbourne i was leaving a job as
a software developer at a bank where i had worked for four and a half years and i was about to start a new role as a
senior developer at telstra purple which is a company that i've always looked up to as employing some
brilliant and amazing people the perth version of the conference i just finished
and i had helped organize it and put a ton of work into it i was having some final chats to
friends and colleagues at the after party with a few drinks in hand and as it was the last time i was going
to see a lot of them they were sharing words of encouragement and praise from their time
working with me so with all these different things happening and kind words being said i was having a
really intense internal battle with imposter syndrome and it was at this very moment when the
organizers for ddd sydney came up to ask me if i could do the loch net
and my brain thought that this had to be some sort of conspiracy there's no way these people that i
looked up to and colleagues that i admired thought this highly of me
my subconscious was telling me they must be up to something but they weren't i was experiencing
imposter syndrome and this was not the first time i've experienced it
and certainly not the last i actually had a moment of imposter syndrome yesterday
when the head of development in my company asked me to help out with a big internal presentation
i immediately said yes but after i hung up the phone i thought wait a minute he must have
made a mistake why would he want me to help out with this but even if you did ask me as a mistake i've
already said yes so now i'm doing it um
experienced this throughout my life and i've continued to battle against it and i've
helped others experience it too so when i was at that bank i had a
secondment as the graduate program manager which meant for the technology graduate
program so that meant that the 14 graduates in the technology department reported into me as their manager
while i ran and developed the program i had to guide the graduates and help them with any problems they may have faced
the most common problem they came to me with were feelings of not meeting expectations and not knowing
what they were doing and not knowing why they got the role that they did
so talk them through these feelings that they were having and what they were experiencing and i helped them battle against it and
what they were dealing with was imposter syndrome it was a bit ironic because while i was
in that role i felt like an imposter i had just finished the graduate program
before moving into the role i had no prior management experience and half of the grads who were reporting
into me were actually older than me and this is a photo of me as the manager
with the grads and i look just like them and many people often mistook me as one of the grads
now looks and age does not matter and it did not make me any less of a leader
but these were all just factors that fed into my imposter syndrome so
how did i get through this how did i ensure that these feelings would not hold me
back and how did i helped the graduates to do the same
i came up with a three-step process to win the battle first i learned to recognize what i was
experiencing was imposter syndrome and recognize when it was happening and what it looked like
then i rationalized the situation i redefined those thoughts and feelings
and reframed them the people around me were not out to get me there was no big
grand scheme to trick me and really what benefit would they have in doing so and finally
i reflected on my accomplishments you know why i had worked hard i had done well and i used these three
things to empower myself to fight against imposter syndrome and a work to flip those beliefs to
prove myself wrong i turned those negative thoughts into positive ones
and i used them as motivation and that motivation encouraged me to say yes and accept that
locked note opportunity and many other opportunities along the way
when i first submitted this talk to ndc i actually submitted it as a lightning talk um mostly because i was afraid for
having to speak for a full hour and yeah we'll see how long actually go time was
but when the conference organizers asked if i would be willing to do it as a full conference talk i
said yes i had to convince myself that i could do it and it was not easy and it's taken a lot
of practice to get over these fears but i was able to do it
and if you struggle with the same thing that is okay we can work through it
so how do you recognize imposter syndrome let's first look at who experiences it
research has found that 70 of people experience imposter syndrome at some point in their life
this is according to a paper that was published in the international journal of behavioral science
the imposter syndrome can be experienced once in your life for many times and for most people it is an
ongoing battle mike from atlassian found that imposter syndrome
does not go away with its success and it can really happen to anyone
however there are some people who are more likely to experience it than others so these are people from
underrepresented communities so like myself as a female in tech or people who are outsiders or
minorities people who suffer from mental health issues like depression
and anxiety people who have experienced abuse or high levels of criticism and people
who are naturally talented or have always had high expectations on them
think about serena williams feeling she's in her sister's shadow
and constantly outside of her comfort zone breaking new ground people are more
likely to feel those insecurities
so graduate level university students were subject to a majority of the
studies and they were found to experience imposter syndrome at a higher rate
and this is because they're in a competitive and stressful environment they're outside of their comfort zone
and outside of their depth of knowledge they're constantly learning new things questioning why they're in the program
over someone else comparing to their classmates and friends who they may see as more successful
and in tech we're continuing to learn new things and i believe these same theories apply
to us we're constantly having to to research and read and publish articles we're you know spending our
time going to conferences and workshops to learn more we're continuing to study and
earn certifications and even as a senior it's really easy to be outshined by that junior
who knows more about that piece of tech the new piece of tech we have to try to stay up to date and
ahead of the curve we're competing sometimes to keep up and that is why imposter syndrome
is such an essential topic in the tech community so what does imposter syndrome look like
well and like in this cartoon we can have trouble accepting compliments we can brush it off make up excuses
say i know they have to say that say we're lucky we're in the right place at the right time we
tend to undermine our own achievements and discount any price that people give us
and when it comes to work we tend to over prepare or completely procrastinate or like i
did by the stock some weird crazy combination of the two we can be workaholics or profession for
perfectionists we can avoid tasks altogether for fear of failing
and not living up to those expectations and for people who are naturally talented we can get frustrated if we
don't understand right away an imposter syndrome is an internal struggle
we often try hard to cover it up while on the inside we're beating ourselves up
worrying that we will soon be found out it's not always visible to others and we might not even
know that we're experiencing it but if we do notice ourselves or any of
our friends doing any of these things we might be experiencing imposter syndrome
so dr valerie young a expert in imposter syndrome has identified that
there are five subtypes that your imposter syndrome may fall into the first
is perfectionist so this type focuses on how well they did something and they
see success as 100 perfection and so anything short of that is considered a
failure and they're constantly focusing on what went wrong or what could have been done better
the next is the natural genius this top likes to focus on how and when
accomplishments happen they look at the ease and speed they were able to complete it
they're the ones that get frustrated when they don't get it the first time and they feel shame if they don't get it
right away and they feel it should come naturally the superhero this type looks at how
many roles they can do at once they tend to be over committed and overwhelmed but if they fall short in
even one of their roles they see it as an overall failure and they feel like they should be able
to handle it all correctly and easily next is the expert this type looks at
what and how much they know or can do so they measure their competence based on the volume of
knowledge or their skill and they fear being exposed as having lack of knowledge or being inexperienced
and last is the soloist so this top cares who completes the task they only see it
as achievement if they did it on their own and they're usually giving credit to others or whatever resources that they
had and they see asking for help as a sign of failure so the type of imposter syndrome you
experience can vary based on the situation and mine personally tends to fall more
into the perfectionist category and for me that means that tasks
can become too daunting because i know it'll be hard to deliver to that 100 standard that i've set for myself so
because of that i might just avoid it all together or once i do start i work overwork myself so much that i
over stress because i'm trying to get it to that perfect state but the ability to recognize the
different types of imposter syndrome will help us to learn how to manage it and how to keep imposter syndrome down
so what are the risks why is impostor syndrome why can it be dangerous what can happen
if we start to lose that battle it can lead to increased depression and
unhappiness general life dissatisfaction it can prevent us from sharing ideas and opinions and
hold us back from accepting or applying to new roles and opportunities it can stop us from speaking up in
meetings or just having our voices heard and it could lead to lack of motivation
and burnout when i was the graduate program manager i had taken on more responsibility than
i ever had before i had those 14 direct reports and i was completely outside of my comfort zone
and on top of that i was trying to keep up with all the different volunteer groups that i was involved in
at the time fitting perfectly into that superhero subtype i was over committed losing motivation
and no longer believed in my abilities i constantly felt like a fraud that they
had made some big mistake giving me that role and i did not belong there i was not happy in the role or just in
my life in general and i was constantly overwhelmed thankfully after a while i was able to
recognize what was happening and that something needed to change i cut back on some
some of my commitments but those negative thoughts and feelings of not belonging and being an
imposter remained but now i was able to recognize what they were
so then i rationalized these thoughts i looked at them in a different light
and i fought against these negative thoughts that were holding me back i thought through does this make
sense i redefined and reframed the situation and i looked at the facts and practiced
thinking like a non-imposter doesn't make sense for people to play a prank on me
how likely was it that someone was going to run up on stage while i was giving that lock note
and pull me off or jump up on this call right now and tell me it was a mistake and i
should stop because there's some big joke the whole time it's it's not very likely at least i i
hope so how do you rationalize these feelings how do you reframe them into
positive ones well there are two main methods to redefining imposter syndrome
the first is thought stopping this is the method of stopping those
negative thoughts and replacing them with positive ones our negative thoughts tend to form a
pattern we often get ourselves into a negative loop that digs us deeper and deeper into a
negative space so before this talk the all the negative thoughts started running into my head
that i'm going to completely mess up this talk people are going to know i have no idea what i'm talking about
it's going to be a big disaster everyone will remember i'll never be able to do a conference talk again and it kind of just goes on and on and
on and once we get into that loop we just start to feel worse and worse
and the farther we go down the more at risk we are of losing this battle
so we need to notice those thoughts recognize them and catch them early on and stop them
we need to bring up another voice to fight against it combat it with positive thoughts even if
initially you do not believe yourself catch yourself thinking i'm a fraud and replace it with
no you're not you can do it it will help you to move forward stop those thoughts in their tracks
rationalize our thoughts and feelings do not define our actions unless we allow them to
the next method is thought shipping this is the idea of not waiting until
the idea is perfect before launch it's very similar to that agile way of
thinking to fail fast and ship it i don't know if you can see but i wore my microsoft azure devops shippit shirt
today to remind me that even though i didn't practice this talk as much as i
would have liked to it is good enough and i must just ship it
it's the 70 rule that's used by the us navy it's a decision-making process that says
when we have 70 percent of the information we must make that call and keep moving
why because moving keeps you safe it makes you less vulnerable it provides
that opportunity to adjust it's very agile to fail fast and learn faster this is the
concept that mike in his talk described as not freezing
thought shipping will push us outside of our comfort zones it'll stimulate growth and creativity
it'll build up self-compassion by allowing us to forgive our mistakes
so if you're suffering from imposter syndrome try out both methods and practice practice practice figure out
which one works for you and get yourself to that state where you're able to recognize and rationalize imposter syndrome
and we can also understand and redefine those talks with those feelings just by talking
about it so share the feelings lean on other people around you when the burden of imposter syndrome is too heavy
to bear as imposters we fear that someone will find out
that and that we'll just be exposed so share those feelings talking about it
with other people is precisely what we need to do having those conversations will help get
the affirmation that these feelings are completely normal and that it's probably not true that you're
a fraud my son was alone when he was feeling like a fraud but then once he spoke to
the other award nominees he found out he was not and this was his libel moment
which drove him to win his battle and sharing my experience helps me to
keep moving forward because i'm able to be open about it and be more comfortable about it
and afterwards many people like to tell me that they've experienced the same thing and so when imposter syndrome is taking
hold you may feel like you're alone but trust me you're not
also remember that it is okay to fail imposter syndrome often comes with an
underlying fear of failure and in order to rationalize our thoughts of being an imposter
we need to keep failure in perspective and redefine what does it mean to fail we like to use
not succeeding as proof that we are a fraud but we need to learn to fight against that because failure is
inevitable learn how to get back up from those failures and move forward
reframe and redefine how we see it and use it as a learning experience and an opportunity for growth
i was worried that no one would actually come to my talk today and my initial thought was that if
no one did it would be a failure but was it really a failure it was a success
to just have my talk accepted to the conference in the first place so reframe it as a stepping stone or a
learning experience break into smaller goals i had a goal to submit talks to
conferences and i achieved that and the next stop step was to have
a talk accepted and then after that is give people an attendance but you want to revisit and update those
goals use them as motivation to work harder continue to learn and move forward get
more talks accepted next time or more people in attendance failure is a part of success
so after recognizing and rationalizing my imposter syndrome and your imposter syndrome we then need
to keep those feelings away and we can do that using our reflection so all three
of these steps work together to build up our ability to win the battle so take a look in the
mirror and see what is there look at your achievements and your accomplishments
hold a retrospective for yourself the same as we would do for our project
completing an objective evaluation of your skills will allow you to distinguish
distinguish reality from what your imposter syndrome is telling you focus on what you have done well but
also what could be improved and use that to move forward and this reflection is critical
it was how i've been able to continue my fight and not let it hold me back
i keep a journal and this is a really good way to do reflection start a list of all of your achievements
write down the things you are proud of write down all of your goals and any stepping stones to success and then
mark them off when you've hit them and reflect on them how much progress have you made
look at your past projects and compare them to current ones have you improved most importantly have
you learned and it's likely that you have probably without even realizing
in my journal i write down all of the things i write down when i spent a lot of time
trying to figure out a task i write down if someone's giving me positive feedback or i gotta talk accepted to a conference
but looking back at these notes always helps me to see how much progress i have made
and it helps turn those negative thoughts into positive ones especially if i've gone into one of those negative
cycles and lifting listing out your success and achievements
can help shift your focus from your weaknesses to your strengths it can create a base of facts to guide
your evaluation and your reflection but we all know that an objective assessment of yourself can be
challenging so we can use the help of others we can ask for feedback
go ask your colleagues how they think you have been performing and what you have done well but also
learn to value constructive criticism and use it to get better
understand that you are actually slowing down your team when you don't ask for help or look to
improve because no one expects you to know everything right away
when the grads would come to me feeling like a fraud i would always tell them to go out and
get feedback from their teammates and they were often surprised with the results
there was one grad who came to me saying she did not understand why this senior
engineer was pairing with her all the time and she felt bad that she was just wasting his time
when i spoke to the senior he said that he enjoyed pairing with her that he was proud of her progress
and she was contributing to the team it was all a matter of perspective
perspective the expectations that the graduates had put on themselves did not match reality we are often
harder on ourselves than anyone else and getting that feedback can help us to
recognize the imposter syndrome rationalize it and then reflect on it we
can shift those thoughts from negative ones to positive ones
and be proud of ourselves in what we have done but we also have to be careful of our
current situation that we have now where we're all virtual and we're all in line
because this means that we're less exposed to the full picture and it's harder to go out to those
colleagues and friends and our virtual world means that we have a very skewed view of what's happening and it's
it can be easy to misinterpret we see the achievements and successes of
others while we only see our own failures
about their finished projects and their all the blogs that they're publishing and the promotion
they received and then we see ourselves that have no side projects have struggled to keep
up with our blog and did not get that promotion social media
encourages unhelpful social comparison and amplifies our dissatisfaction with ourselves so we
need to learn how to separate the virtual world from reality we can use those facts in
that reflection of ourselves and what we know to be true of others and we can reflect on the positives
a friend told mike from atlassian you are doing something right so you should probably
just keep going think through how did you get to where you are was it luck or was it really the hard
work work that you put in someone gave you that role that job and that opportunity for a
reason bill gates said here don't compare yourself with anyone in this world
if you do so you're insulting yourself everyone has their own story and their
own pathways their own journey and their own talents and you were awesome for your own reason
and they hired you not because they expected you to know everything right away but because they saw potential in you
and the truth is most of us don't actually know what we're doing but that's okay
use it as motivation to go out and learn more challenge those negative thoughts and
practice positive self-talk practice bringing up that second voice
in your head from the negative one start to challenge it and fight back flip any
sort of limiting beliefs and motivate yourself to prove yourself wrong say no you can do it
you can do the talk fight back and tell yourself that you're good enough but also remember that it's
okay to fail the important thing is to learn and reflect on your experience in the grad manager
role i had recognized that i was experiencing imposter syndrome
and i'd worked through rationalizing those thoughts but then i realized that
i had actually done well i was able to reflect on how i got there and i could see that
there was actually no mistake in them giving me that role however i was then able to see clearly
that the role was just not for me i missed the hands up on tech and i just
wasn't happy so i ended up actually cutting this condiment short and moving back to a
developer role but i was able to stay motivated and use my experience as a positive one
and i continued to reflect on my achievements i looked back at the steps i had taken
so far and any goals i had reached and i learned and created new ones and i
practiced recognizing rationalizing and reflecting and with that we can beat imposter
syndrome so what can you do we've so far talked a
lot about how we can work on imposter syndrome for ourselves but what can you do for others
not everyone experiences imposter syndrome and that's you're really lucky if you're
one of the ones who don't but we can all help those who do if you're a team leader
a friend or just a colleague you can support other people in their fight you can become a mentor to those who you
see potential in who you think might need that extra push you can educate someone who you think
might be experiencing it you can provide the tools that they need to beat from foster syndrome
you can teach them how to recognize it and how to rationalize their feelings and then reflect on their
accomplishments you can guide them to opportunities they would not seek themselves before
fear of failing as a graduate myself i shared an interest in
leadership roles with a colleague and so when the role for graduate manager came up
he approached me and he told me that he thought i would be good at it and i should play
my immediate reaction was no way i would not even be able to get the role that i won't be any good at it but he believed
in me and that made me believe in myself and with his support i applied and i was
successful later on when i was applying to roles over in melbourne
i applied to senior level positions despite at the time being a mid-tier developer and i only did this because my manager
had told me that i was reaching that senior level and so without him telling me that i
would not have been confident enough to do so
so create a mentor program in your company or just get involved in the existing one give new starters a
buddy someone they can lean on someone that can go to with questions and show them support
imposter syndrome can strike at all levels so it means that we need to have the support system there too
everyone needs a champion one to put their name forward especially if that person is
usually hesitant to do it themselves and having a one-soft conversation is
not enough we need to create a plan and offer ongoing support
and we can encourage that self-reflection by driving goal setting and having regular catch-up meetings to
see how they're progressing studies have shown that coaching and career planning leads to
a positive effect on people's self-confidence and that it pushes them up in the fight
against imposter syndrome so you can be the one that gives that confidence to somebody who needs it
we talked about how imposters should go out and collect feedback on themselves but you can also go out and give it you
can reach out and provide it to people and you can help them reflect on their accomplishments
help them with that thought stitch stopping and thought shipping tell people when they have done well
tell them that you love their work create a system for your team to recognize each other
and celebrate success i know microsoft and linkedin microsoft teams and
linkedin both have built-in tools that allow you to send praise to your colleagues
and you should have some sort of system within your company to recognize each other as well
in in my company we have nominations for a monthly discover master influence award where
you can nominate a teammate who has gone above and beyond and in return they receive a gift card from
from the company for their efforts even if initially they brush it off or make up
some excuse that continuous feedback can help wear down the negative thoughts and build up the positive funds so give
people credit for their strengths and let them know why you hired them
if your colleague always credits their success to luck or the help of others reframe it for them let them know what
they have achieved and use facts focus on what they have done well and how they did it well credit their
success to internal factors and help them to internalize it
you can also nurture a growth mindset within your colleagues the growth mindset is the idea that you
can develop intelligence and skill and it helps have an open mind for learning for accepting failure and
change and a growth mindset leads to higher productivity more achievement and higher life
satisfaction a fixed mindset on the other hand is the belief that intelligence is static
and your ability cannot be changed and will hold you back and unfortunately a
fixed mindset often accompanies imposter syndrome so and it will drive those worries that
will never be good enough so develop a growth mindset within your team
to challenge this help them view a struggle as an opportunity and make sure not to
reprimand mistakes but use them as a learning experience for someone when they've attempted a new
approach in a well-directed effort instead of just imprisoning praising their intelligence
guide them in the self-reflection of their journey
outside of mentoring and support we can create a positive culture and working environment we can foster
community and diversity and inclusion we can remove a blame culture and any
sort of competition creating a safe place where people can be themselves
where they can share ideas challenge one another and learn in a positive way dr young
found a sense of belonging fosters confidence and we know that minorities and people
outside of their comfort zone are more likely to experience imposter syndrome so if we focus on culture and diversity
inclusion within the workplace we can remove those barriers the more people who look and sound like
you the more confident you feel and the more welcoming and accepting people are more comfortable you will be
and with a higher confidence and comfort the more likely your team will be to speak up
to believe in themselves and work to their full potential
so imposter syndrome can be good it does not always have to be a bad thing we can use it as a challenge
to prove ourselves and just everyone else wrong mike in his talk found himself in a
situation where he actually did not know what people thought he should but instead of letting it make him
freeze he used it as an excuse to go out and learn he might have been motivated out of that fear of looking
like a fraud but he used that fear as a force for good you can motivate yourself to take
on that new challenge to prove yourself and everyone else wrong remember that it's okay to not know
everything it's okay to fail keep learning and fight against imposter syndrome it
can make us stronger through that self-reflection and learning we start to recognize our feelings it
drives self-awareness emotional intelligence and it helps us to become more open and connect with
others we start to become comfortable with being uncomfortable
and we learn more about ourselves we grow in open minds and become more accepting of change and
things to come we are more productive more confident and more successful we
become a better leader a better mentor and a better friend remember that imposter syndrome can
happen to anyone at any level no matter how successful they appear whether they're just
starting out or the industry expert their imposter syndrome might be there and it's not always
visible so know when to ask for advice and give support and use it to learn and share
your experiences and feelings be open about it practice thought shifting and thought stopping
create a positive environment for yourself and your team and be aware of it help those around you
fight it so we can recognize those negative
thoughts and feelings of being an imposter we can look out for those people who are at higher risk
we're making excuses who are always over preparing or procrastinating
we can support one another to try out for new opportunities and celebrate success we can tell people
i love your work and help them to move on help them to
rationalize the situation to think through the internal feelings of being a phony
did you get to where you are by luck or was it your skills talents and expertise
don't compare yourself to others reflect on your accomplishments in your own journey
and look at what you have been able to achieve we can motivate ourselves to believe we can do it we can
